The  Project  follows  a  sector  lending  approach  and  supports  the 
Government’s  objectives  of  decentralization,  poverty  reduction, 
and  human  development  by  providing  (i)  improved  rural  water 
infrastructure  services,  and

(ii) training  programs  to  strengthen  institutional  capacity.  The 
Project  consists  of  two  parts:  Part  A:  physical  infrastructure  and 
Part B: institutional development. Part A consists of 12 subprojects, 
each  covering  a  cluster  of  villages.  The  subprojects  will  include 
developing  and  rehabilitating  piped  water  supply  systems,  public 
and  school  latrines,  and  wastewater  facilities.  Part  B  includes  a 
capacity-building  program,  a  hygiene  and  sanitation  education 
program, and consulting services for project management support. 
The  Project  will  cover  two  oblasts  (provinces),  Kashkadarya  and 
Navoi, and will provide basic WSS infrastructure services to about 
250,000  people,  about  30%  of  whom  are  living  below  the  poverty 
line.

The procurement of civil works, goods, and services to be financed 
by  the  ADB  loan  will  be  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines  for  Procurement.  International  competitive  bidding 
procedures will be applied for supply contracts estimated to cost at 
least  $1  million  equivalent.  Supply  contracts  worth  less  than 
$1 million equivalent will follow international shopping procedures, 
except  for  supply  contracts  with  a  value  of  less  than  $100,000 
equivalent,  which  may  be  procured  by  direct  purchase.  Local 
competitive  bidding  procedures  will  be  applied  for  civil  works 
contracts that are valued at less than $2 million.  
 
The  Project  will  require  680  person-months  of  consulting  services 
(50  person-months  of  international  and  630  person-months  of 
domestic)  for  (i)  review  of  detailed  design,  (ii)  construction 
supervision, 
(iv)  community 
finance  and  accounting, 
development, and (v) project management. The consultants will be 
engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  using  quality  and  cost  based  selection  (QCBS)  and 
other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of 
domestic consultants. 
 
The  Project  is  expected  to  benefit  170  villages  with  populations 
ranging  from  300  to  8,000.  Overall,  about  250,000  people,  about 
30% of whom are living below the poverty line, will benefit directly 
from  the  Project  through  provision  of  potable  quality  piped  water 
supply  facilities;  improved  wastewater  drainage  facilities;  and 
public, school, and private latrines. The Project will improve health 
conditions  by  reducing  waterborne  diseases.  Related  benefits 
include  time  and  cost  savings  from  purchasing,  fetching,  treating, 
and storing water; improved public and family hygiene and health; 
reduced  medical  outlays;  and  increased  productivity  days.  The 
core  subprojects’  economic  internal  rate  of  return  is  23%  to  36%. 
Support  for  decentralized  community  management  and  capacity 
building will enhance the efficiency and sustainability of rural WSS 
services in Uzbekistan. 
 

 
Risks and Assumptions  Three  possible  risks  have  been  identified.  First,  the  possibility  of 
delays  in  project  implementation  caused  by  weak  institutional 
capability  to  implement,  operate,  and  maintain  the  water  supply 
systems  has  been  addressed  through  clear  delineation  of  agency 
inclusion  of  coordination  mechanisms.

of the expanded water supply systems. The Project will be closely

A. 
 
2. 
The  Government’s  development  objectives  are  to  promote  economic  growth,  reduce 
poverty,  and  provide  balanced  regional  development—including  improved  water  supply  and 
sanitation (WSS) services. The country’s WSS facilities are often poorly designed, inadequately 
maintained,  and  in  a  poor  state  of  repair.  Rural  water  supply  has  particularly  suffered  from 
budget  cuts  since  independence.  Formerly,  an  estimated  70%  of  all  rural  villages  had  piped 
potable water supply. Lack of funding for operation and maintenance (O&M) is the main reason 
that  many  water  supply  systems  are  constantly  out  of  service.  In  spite  of  the  Government’s 
efforts  to  reestablish  the  level  of  water  supply  service,  the  percentage  of  villages  with  piped 
water supply is currently relatively low. Rural areas in the oblasts of Kashkadarya and Navoi are 
particularly poorly served with piped water supply. Recent surveys show that only about 30% of 
villages in Kashkadarya and Navoi oblasts have access to piped water supply. Annual funding 
to  the  sector  is  generally  limited  to  routine  maintenance  and  repairs.  The  level  of  tariffs—
targeted to cover O&M costs—is low, collection management is poor, and insufficient money is 
raised to support efficient operation.  
 
3. 
Lack  of  adequate  WSS  services  also  has  a  large  negative  impact  on  community  health, 
especially  the  poor.  In  rural  areas,  people  often  have  to  walk  long  distances  only  to  obtain 
contaminated  water  from  untreated  sources.  There  are  few  wastewater  collection  systems  in 
rural  areas  and  waste  disposal  infrastructure  is  below  acceptable  standards.  Insufficient  and 
polluted  drinking  water  supplies,  combined  with  poor  sanitation  and  hygiene  practices,  are 
directly  linked  to  the  high  incidence  of  waterborne  diseases.  As  a  consequence  of  major 
government  reforms  in  the  health  sector  since  1998,  expected  life  expectancy  at  birth  has 
increased  and  the  infant  mortality  rate  has  decreased  substantially.  Nevertheless,  maternal, 
child,  and  infant  mortality  remain  high.  Water-related  diseases  such  as  hepatitis  A,  typhoid 
fever,  skin  allergies,  and  kidney  disease  are  widespread,  particularly  in  rural  areas.  In  the 
Kashkadarya and Navoi oblasts, indicators of infectious morbidity remain significantly high.  
 
B. 
 
4. 
Sector Policies. Since the promulgation of the Law on Water and Water Use, 1993, the 
Government  has  gradually  extended  and  strengthened  the  legislative  framework  covering 
Uzbekistan’s needs in the WSS sector, particularly in rural areas. Needs include improvement of 
physical and institutional structures, promotion of sector decentralization, conservation of water 
resources,  and  implementation  of  sound  tariff  and  cost-recovery  policies.  Uzbekistan’s  WSS 
policy  is  now  underpinned  by  three  legal  instruments:  (i)  the  national  10-year  water  supply 
development  plan  approved  by  the  Cabinet  of  Ministers  in  1999,  (ii)  the  Resolution  of  the 
Cabinet  of  Ministers  approved  in  2003  (RCM)  No.  405,  and  (iii)  the  latest  annual  public 
investment program approved by the Cabinet of Ministers. 
 
5.

national  water  supply  development  plan;  (ii)  attain  financial  sustainability  through  an  effective

Part A: Physical Infrastructure  

 
18.  Part A includes 12 subprojects, covering about 170 villages with populations ranging from 
300 to 8,000, a total of about 250,000. Each subproject will cover a cluster of up to 20 villages 
within  one  rayon  and  comprise  an  integrated  water  supply  system,  including  improvement  of 
sanitation  facilities.  The  subprojects  will  consist  of  the  development  or  rehabilitation  and 
upgrading  of  piped  water  supply  systems,  construction  of  public  and  school  latrines,  and 
participatory improvement of wastewater drainage facilities. The development and expansion of 
the water supply systems will include construction and/or rehabilitation of water source intakes, 
construction  of  pumping  stations,  treatment  facilities,  storage  reservoirs,  transmission  and 
distribution  pipelines,  and  individual  yard  or  house  connections.  The  subprojects  will  derive 
supplies from different types of water sources. Most subprojects will use groundwater sources, 
and  will  require  development  and/or  rehabilitation  of  water  supply  systems  and  drilling  of 
production  wells.  The  new  development  of  water  supply  will  be  coordinated  with  wastewater 
drainage measures consisting of basic improvements to village drainage networks. Public and 
school toilets will be rehabilitated and, where feasible, connected to septic tanks.  
 
19.  The physical infrastructure component will cover around 10% of the approximately 1,700 
villages  in  the  two  project  oblasts.  About  1,200  villages  (70%)  do  not  have  any  formal  piped 
water supply system, while the remaining 500 villages (30%) are supplied from trunk mains or 
local  sources.  About  11%  (250,000)  of  the  total  rural  population  in  the  project  oblasts 
(2.2 million) will  be  covered  by  the  12  subprojects.  Of  the  12  subprojects—each  involving  one 
rayon and an integrated water supply system covering up to 20 villages—7 systems will utilize 
groundwater sources distributed from trunk mains and 5 will be supplied from local groundwater 
sources. On average, the per capita investment cost is about $140.  
 
20.  Settlements in the project area are divided into three major categories: (i) settlements in 
areas  without  groundwater  resources,  which  can  be  supplied  by  long-distance  interregional  or 
regional  trunk  mains;  (ii)  settlements  that  can  be  supplied  from  a  locally  developed  water 
resource (essentially groundwater); and (iii) settlements in remote areas whose only alternative 
supply is the desalination of locally available salinized groundwater. In selecting settlements for 
the  subprojects,  priority  is  given  to  settlements  with  no  water  supply  or  a  nonworking  water 
supply  system,  located  near  a  reliable  source  of  fresh  water.  In  addition,  the  following  criteria

efficiently plan, implement, operate, and maintain the WSS systems. The program will provide:

Economic and Financial Aspects 

1. 

Economic Aspects 

 
51.  The economic analysis covers both the Project as a whole, and the individual subprojects 
(Appendix  13).  For  the  Project  as  a  whole,  the  analysis  covers  the  economic  rationale  for 
government  intervention,  and  the  goals  and  general  design  of  the  investment  plan.  The 
economic rationale is sound, based on social responsibility to provide basic social services and 
controlling  natural  monopoly  (water  supply).  The  goals  of  the  investment  plan  are  to  meet 
targets  for  rural  water  supply  development  and  control  of  the  spread  of  waterborne  disease, 
especially  in  hard-to-reach  areas.  The  targets  are  clearly  defined,  legally  established,  and 
consistent with government goals for sustainable development in rural water supply, as defined 
in  the  National  Water  Supply  Development  Program  (NWSDP),  2000–2010.  The  plan  to  meet 
targets is based on centralized water supply systems designed using least-cost solutions based 
on  type  and  availability  of  water  resources  and  variations  in  scope,  design  technologies, 
location,  and  planning  horizon.  Other  project  goals  consistent  with  NWSDP  include  cost 
recovery  and  sustainability  tariffs,  conservation  and  economic  use  of  water,  and  improved 
decentralization.  Economic  cost-benefit  analysis  for  the  individual  subprojects  was  also 

 

 undertaken to strengthen the economic justification. The economic internal rate of return for the 
four representative subprojects range between 23% and 36%. 
 

2. 

Financial Aspects 

 
52.  Financial  evaluation  of  the  four  representative  core  subprojects  was  undertaken  in  real 
terms using constant April 2005 prices. The project cost estimates and financial projections in 
nominal  terms  after  tax  were  converted  to  real  terms  by  adjusting  for  foreign  and  domestic 
inflation and currency fluctuation. The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) for each subproject 
is  more  than  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital,  computed  on  an  after-tax  basis.  The 
subprojects are considered both financially viable and sustainable. The FIRRs for the four core 
subprojects range between 6.6% and 7.9%, averaging 7.2%. This compares favorably with the 
weighted average cost of capital of 4.5%. Sensitivity and risk analyses indicate that the FIRR is 
robust  under  adverse  conditions.  Projected  tariffs  are  within  the  accepted  limit,  so  they  are 
affordable to low-income group households. 
 
53.  Financial projections were prepared for each of the subproject entities in accordance with 
ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the  Financial  Governance  and  Management  of  Investment  Projects 
Financed  by  ADB  (2002)  and  ADB’s  Framework  for  the  Economic  and  Financial  Appraisal  of 
Urban Development Sector Projects (1994) to assess the financial viability and sustainability of 
each  subproject  (Appendix  14).  Projected  financial  statements  indicate  that  financial  revenues 
will be sufficient to cover O&M costs from the first year of operation and a substantial portion of 
depreciation  from  years  1–4.  By  year  5,  the  subprojects  will  have  achieved  financial  self-
sufficiency  to  attain  full  cost  recovery  during  the  remaining  repayment  period.  Details  of  the 
financial analysis for the four core subprojects are presented in Supplementary Appendix S. 
 

3. 

Affordability Analysis and Project Sustainability 

 
54.  The water supply subprojects will be community driven from the initial stage of formulation 
and  construction,  and  DWCUs  will  participate  in  O&M  of  the  schemes  as  self-supporting 
agencies to the extent possible. Based on the survey undertaken, the rural population appears 
willing to increase water services payments. Expressed as a percentage of average household 
income  of  the  low-income  group,  the  tariffs  are  expected  to  vary  between  2.3%  and  5.7%  for 
low-income households in Kashkadarya (4.0% average), and between 1.9% and 7.5% in Navoi 
(4.7%  average).  These  values  are  within  the  accepted  standards  from  3%  to  5%.  Since  it  is 
likely  that  poorer  households  will  collect  water  from  public  standpipes  at  a  fixed  monthly  rate, 
the  cost  will  be  much  less  than  for  households  with  in-house  connections.  The  subproject 
revenues are expected to cover O&M costs and depreciation to ensure project sustainability.

SUMMARY OF WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION SECTOR POLICY 
 

The Basis of the Policy 

A. 
 
Uzbekistan’s water supply and sanitation policy (the Policy), particularly as it relates to 
1. 
the rural sector, is underpinned by three legal instruments: (i) the national 10-year water supply 
development  scheme  approved  by  the  Cabinet  of  Ministers  in  1999,  (ii)  the  resolution  of  the 
Cabinet  of  Ministers  approved  in  2003  (RCM  No.  405),  and  (iii)  the  latest  annual  investment 
program approved by the Cabinet of Ministers. 
 
2. 
The Government of Uzbekistan places a high priority on the sustainable development of 
rural  settlements  as  a  precondition  for  fostering  countrywide  development.  The  Government 
prefers  an  integrated  rural  development  policy,  which  targets  the  overall  sustainability  of  rural 
settlements and sets the following main objectives: (i) improvement of environmental conditions, 
(ii)  improvement  of  rural  incomes,  (iii)  provision  of  adequate  housing,  (iv)  availability  of  social 
and health services, and (v) coverage of people’s needs in drinking water and sanitation.  
 
3. 
Uzbekistan  is  a  signatory  to  Agenda  21.  As  such,  it  has  adopted  the  principle  of 
“rationalization  of  utilization  of  land,  water  and  other  natural  resources  to  conserve  their 
reserves  for  forthcoming  generations”  as  one  of  its  major  goals  for  sustainable  development. 
Further,  recognizing  the  significant  disparities  in  the  levels  of  development  between  urban 
centers  and  rural  villages,  the  Government’s  support  for  the  transition  to  sustainable 
development  prioritizes:  (i)  the  needs  of  rural  settlements,  (ii)  redressing  regional  disparities, 
and  (iii)  addressing  the  needs  of  the  poorer  segment  of  the  population  based  on  the  overall 
principle  that  sustainable  development  of  rural  settlements  determines  the  sustainability  of 
countrywide development.  
 
4. 
The  Policy  emphasizes  the  adoption  of  cost-effective  construction  technologies  and 
improvement  of  management  procedures  oriented  towards  economic  use  of  water  and 
reduction of water wastage through: (i) installation of water meters; (ii) elimination of leakages, 
illegal  connections,  and  other  water  losses;  (iii)  further  reduction  of  specific  rates  of  water 
demand; and (iv) improvement of water tariff collection performance.  
 
5. 
The  Government  has  prepared  and  started  a  number  of  national  programs  targeted  at 
contributing  to  sustainable  overall  development  of  rural  settlements,  funded  by  the  national 
budget, as well as loans and grants from external sources. In the rural sanitation subsector, the 
focus  of  government  efforts  has  been  on  upgrading  basic  sanitation  services  and  fostering 
school sanitation and hygiene through a series of integrated projects. Nine interregional water 
supply systems are targeted for completion by 2010. These constitute the least-cost solution for 
the supply of large areas, in comparison with the main alternative, which is desalination. 
 
6. 
Recognizing the urgency of these tasks, the Republic of Uzbekistan has taken steps to 
develop a comprehensive policy covering its water supply and sanitation (WSS) sector. The key 
objectives of the Policy are to: (i) improve water sector services through a national water supply 
development  plan;  (ii)  attain  financial  sustainability  through  an  effective  tariff  system  and  cost 
recovery; (iii) plan adequate investments with domestic and external funding; (iv) achieve further 
decentralization  of  WSS  services;  (v)  encourage  private  sector  participation  and  public-private 
partnerships in the sector; (vi) implement hygiene and sanitation education programs in schools; 
(vii) achieve improved livelihood conditions, particularly for the benefit of women in rural areas; 
(viii)  ensure  environmental  compliance  by  encouraging  conservative  development  of  water 
resources, economic use of water, consistent water quality control, and sound management of

2.

implementation,  including  the  state  housing  support  program,  health  reform  program,  national 
personnel training program, water supply and sanitation program, natural gas supply program, 
state  family  protection  program,  and  other  programs.  In  the  public  utilities  sector,  the 
Government  has  recognized  the  most  acute  social  problem  as  the  lack  of  adequate  supply  of

of the Aral Sea, and the pollution and depletion of surface and groundwater resources.

supply.  In  implementing  its  water  supply  program,  the  Government  has  placed  particular

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Uzbekistan: 
 
Poverty  remains  pervasive  in  Uzbekistan.  Investments  in  social  infrastructure  such  as  clean  water  are  considered 
important inputs for sustainable poverty reduction. Although access to potable water is not a problem for low-income 
households,  water  shortage—especially  in  rural  areas—equally  affects  low-income  and  well-off  households.  This 
makes poverty deeper, as it entails significant extra costs to meet basic living needs. Direct losses because of lack of 
access  to  clean  potable  water  and  sanitary  facilities  include  the  following:  (i)  high  time  and  labor  cost  related  to 
delivering water and doing household work, especially for women and children; (ii) high costs of coping strategies for 
water shortage, including the construction of water reservoirs; (iii) high disease incidence; (iv) limited opportunities for 
self-employment development, especially in the service sector. 
 
Some 25% and 33% of families in Kashkadarya and Navoi oblasts pay about $0.4 per month on average for potable 
water. However, households that buy water from water vendors spend $42 per year on average in Kashkadarya oblast 
and  $23  in  Navoi  oblast.  The  remaining  households  do  not  pay  for  water  in  monetary  terms,  but  expend  enormous 
time and labor inputs in water delivery, and incur losses related to disease treatment and nonattendance of school by 
children due to diseases, etc. The Project will benefit about 250,000 people, more than 30% of whom are considered 
poor, in the two project oblasts, through the provision of improved access to safe and reliable water supply and better 
sanitation  facilities.  Technical,  economic,  and  financial  analyses  confirm  that  least-cost  long-term  solutions  involve 
development  and/or  rehabilitation  of  water  sources  and  water  supply  systems.  This  approach  will  bring  social  and 
economic benefits, including poverty reduction, financial sustainability at affordable levels for project beneficiaries, and 
positive environmental impacts. Institutional solutions and community participation in design and implementation of the 
subprojects will enhance the efficiency and sustainability of the sector program and subprojects.   
 
At least one family member in 10% of families in Kashkadarya oblast and 16% in Navoi oblast suffered from disease 
related to low water quality and lack of access to sanitary facilities. In Novbahor rayon of Navoi oblast, the figure rises 
to 36%. The most common water-related diseases are diarrhea, dysentery, gastrointestinal and kidney diseases, and 
hepatitis А. Average expenses in 2004 reached $85 in 5% of families that had to spend money on treatment of water-

The  rationale  for  government  intervention  results  from  increasing  concern  over  the 
worsening  water  supply  situation  in  the  rural  settlements,  defined  by  low  and  declining 
coverage,  made  worse  by  the  slow  pace  of  development  in  the  sector.  Despite  government

Although 70% of the total rural settlements are currently within reach of centralized water 
3. 
supply,  only  about  30–40%  of  the  rural  population  still  has  real  access  to  partially  functioning 
piped water supply systems nationwide. The reason is that most of these supply systems are in 
various stages of deterioration and some are dysfunctional. As a result, residents are forced to 
use alternative, unsafe sources of water from rivers or canals. Recognition by the Government 
of  the  seriousness  of  the  problem  led  to  reforms  being  undertaken  in  the  sector.  Recent 
regulations have been passed to promote decentralization in the provision of these services. In 
the  case  of  rural  water  supply,  the  responsibility  for  and  ownership  of  assets  have  been 
conferred on the oblast or provincial administration, with operation and maintenance handled by 
the  oblast  vodokanal  through  the  rayon  or  district  vodokanal  under  its  stewardship.  By  detail, 
water  supply  services  in  rural  settlements  are  under  the  rayon  vodokanal.  However,  studies 
show that where such centralized systems exist, services only continue to deteriorate because 
little  could  be  done  in  improving  and  rehabilitating  the  systems  due  to  lack  of  funds. 
Unrealistically  low  tariffs  with  a  poor  basis  or  no  basis  of  determination  result  in  very  limited 
revenue generation. Additionally, rayon vodokanals depend on subsidies from the oblast budget 
to cover financial needs for large-scale system repair or extension works. Consequently, under 
the  present  institutional  context,  rayon  vodokanals  are  neither  institutionally  nor  financially 
independent water utilities. Water supply is rationed only a few hours a day and schedules are 
often not met. Many rayon vodokanals on which rural water supply depends are characterized 
by  inefficient  operations,  poor  service  levels,  poor  state  of  repair,  weak  institutional  capacity, 
scarcity  of  water  resources,  and  financial  inadequacy.  In  the  past,  agro-vodokanals  managed 
rural  systems,  as  most  are  situated  along  agricultural  areas  encompassing  rural  settlements. 
Some agro-vodokanals still exist but are now being gradually phased out by virtue of a law that 
declares their abolition. Another entity, the Obi Hayot, continues to be a service provider in rural 
settlements,  but  its  interests  lie  in  managing  systems  that  guarantee  profits,  and  there  are 
probably no networks of the scale targeted in the proposed sector investment plan, which could 
offer the same incentive in the near term.

9.

planning  mechanisms  like  the  Public  Investment  Program  (PIP),  while  local  urban  and  rural

alternative water supply sources. The NWSDP also gives particular emphasis to: (i) adoption of 
least-cost technologies, (ii) demand management directed towards economic use of water and 
reduction of wastage, (iii) financial sustainability through gradual cost recovery of infrastructure 
capital and targeted subsidies, and (iv) further decentralization of sector services.

Design of the Plan 

 
15. 
The  goals  of  the  plan  will  be  achieved  at  least  cost  through  centralized  water  supply 
systems  developed  from  least-cost  alternatives.  A  structured  approach  will  be  adopted  for  the 
appraisal and approval of subprojects included in the plan. Subprojects will be selected based 
on availability and the type of water resources, and must also be among the number of villages 
that  are  in  most  urgent  need  of  water  supply.  For  Kashkadarya  and  Navoi,  the  oblast 
administrations  must  also  submit  a  request  providing  evidence  that  the  basic  conditions  for 
inclusion of subprojects are fulfilled. These include: (i) willingness of the settlers to establish and 
constitute a DWCU and select a board from among union members; (ii) willingness to set, apply, 
and  pay  water  tariffs  for  water  consumed;  and  (iii)  commitment  of  the  local  administrations  to 
implement a resettlement plan for settlers that may be affected by the constructed facilities. A 
social  survey  conducted  in  the  two  oblasts  reports  a  relatively  high  demand  for  the  proposed 
service.  The  willingness  of  beneficiaries  to  pay  for  centralized  water  supply  is  84%  in 
Kashkadarya and 74% in Navoi. 
 
The  composition  of  subprojects  is  determined  foremost  by  water  resource  type  and

availability.  In  areas  without  groundwater  resources,  contiguous  or  close-to-contiguous 
settlements at a reasonable distance from an existing trunk main may constitute a subproject.

Where  groundwater  is  available,  a  subproject  may  include  a  cluster  of  settlements  served  by 
individual  production  wells.  A  single  well  source  may  serve  one  or  several  villages.  Each 
subproject may comprise 10 to 20 villages, all within the political boundaries of a single rayon. 
Each  centralized  water  supply  system  will  be  designed  at  least  cost,  in  terms  of  location,

the  plan  prevent  all  investments  from  being  made  simultaneously.  Availability  of  local 
contractors,  timely  release  of  counterpart  funds,  and  capacity  of  project  management  and 
design institutes will be considered. 
 
17. 
Uzbekistan’s  freshwater  resources  are  limited  and  localized,  particularly  groundwater, 
which  commonly  allows  the  development  of  the  most  economic  water  supply  systems 
alternatives  for  small  and  decentralized  systems.  The  scarcity  of  the  resource  also  limits 
alternative  solutions  for  water  supply,  particularly  for  small  centers.  Surface  water  of  quality 
suitable for development is rare and can only be developed economically for large-scale water 
supplies.  In  implementing  the  plan  on  a  large  scale,  the  Government  has  prioritized  and 
invested efforts in the construction and rehabilitation of long-distance, interregional, or regional 
water supply transmission systems, fed from centralized, proven sustainable, water resources, 
as  the  least-cost  choice.  This  is  in  comparison  with  the  next  most  expensive  and 
environmentally unfriendly solution: desalination of locally available groundwater, as a strategic 
plan  to  meet  the  goal  of  covering  most  of  the  country’s  population  with  water  supply  at 
affordable costs. 
 
18. 
For supply of rural settlements with drinking water, the main option is the development of 
local groundwater resources, when available, as the most economic solution for water supply. 
This is true particularly when several settlements can be fed from one single production well. In 
arid areas and areas without freshwater resources, the least-cost solution for the supply of small 
agglomerations  remains  the  supply  from  the  trunk  mains,  provided  the  distance  of  the 
settlement  from  the  trunk  main  is  affordable  in  terms  of  pipeline  investments.  The  least-cost 
solution  in  this  case  consists  of  having  a  maximum  number  of  neighboring  villages  supplied 
from  a  single  pumping  station,  a  model  similar  to  that  adopted  for  systems  supplied  from 
groundwater  wells.  Similar  types  of  models  have  been  developed  and  applied  in  defining 
subprojects  and  selecting  least-cost  improvement  schemes  under  the  technical  assistance  for 
the proposed Project.

One  of  the  procedural  requirements  for  subproject  selection  and  appraisal  is  the 
development of feasibility studies, which include both financial and economic analysis, for each 
subproject  under  consideration.  Inclusion  of  the  subproject  in  the  list  would  require  subproject

standard  financial  and  economic  cost-benefit  analysis.  Financial  viability  would  require  the 
financial internal rate of return (FIRR) to be higher than the cost of capital, and that benefits are 
based on tariffs affordable to consumers. Economic viability would be measured in terms of the 
economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR),  which  should  be  greater  than  the  opportunity  cost  of 
capital.  In  instances  where  economic  benefits  are  not  quantifiable,  economic  analysis  will  be 
supplemented  with  socioeconomic  evaluation  that  would  aid  the  assessment.  A  critical 
sensitivity  analysis  will  complete  the  cost-benefit  analyses  and  the  socioeconomic  evaluation 
considering the impacts of alternative assumptions, risks, and imponderables.
